article.headline: Trump says he might spend his own money on his re-election campaign: âIf I have to, I wouldâ
article.body: President Donald Trump on Tuesday said he might spend his own money on his re-election campaign, with the remark coming a week after Democratic challenger Joe Biden announced a record-breaking fundraising haul for August. âIf I have to, I would,â Trump said, regarding the possibility that he might use some of his own fortune, estimated at $2.5 billion, toward his run for a second term. âIf we did need â we donât, because we have much more money than we had last time going into the last two months, I think double and triple â but if we needed any more, Iâd put it up personally.â âWhatever it takes â we have to win,â the president added, as he spoke with reporters before heading to Florida. Trump was making visits to two key swing states on Tuesday, giving a speech in Florida in the afternoon and an address in North Carolina in the evening. Trump has discussed spending as much as $100 million of his own money on his re-election campaign, if necessary, according to a Bloomberg News report on Tuesday citing unnamed sources. He contributed $66 million to his 2016 campaign, but it would be unprecedented for an incumbent president to put his own money toward winning a second term, the report added. Bidenâs campaign and its affiliates last week announced they raised $364.5 million in August, breaking the previous monthly fundraising record for a White House campaign. Related:How Bidenâs war chest is catching up to Trumpâs â in one chart Trumpâs re-election campaign and its affiliates on Wednesday announced an August haul that came in below Bidenâs, getting more than $210 million, and a New York Times report on Monday said some people inside the campaign are forecasting a cash crunch with less than 60 days until the Nov. 3 election. Thatâs after the campaign and its affiliates raised $1.1 billon from the beginning of 2019 through July, but then spent more than $800 million. Trumpâs campaign manager, Bill Stepien, pushed back on suggestions of a cash crunch on Tuesday, saying his team is âvery comfortable and confident in where weâre spending and how much weâre spending and how much weâre going to have down the stretch.â He took over as campaign manager in July. âWe are now carefully managing the budget,â Stepien told reporters on a conference call. âI consider it to be among the â if not the most important â tasks for any campaign manager.â âFrom this day forward to Election Day, we will have more recent resources to spend than we had in 2016, and it wonât be close â itâll be by a factor of two times or three times what we had to spend on the campaign we were a part of in 2016,â Stepien added. A campaignâs financial condition is a closely watched measure of viability, along with polling data. Trump also often touts the performance of the stock market SPX, +0.87% DJIA, +0.56% Â , which closed lower again Tuesday after selling off last week. Trumpâs threat on Monday to âdecoupleâ the U.S. economy from China added to market jitters during Tuesdayâs session, Wall Street analysts said. In a RealClearPolitics moving average of polls focused on top battleground states that are likely to decide the election, Biden was drawing support of 48.2% of voters as of Tuesday, ahead of Trumpâs 45.3%. Betting markets were giving Biden a 53.7% chance of winning vs. Trumpâs 45.7%. However, a Las Vegas Review-Journal report on Wednesday said the Nevada rallies have been canceled because of the stateâs restrictions on in-person gatherings during the coronavirus pandemic. Biden attacked Trumpâs record in Florida ahead of the Republican incumbentâs speech, which was billed as covering his administrationâs âenvironmental accomplishments for the people of Florida.â Biden said in a statement that the president âhas opened up additional public lands, both on land and offshore, to the possibility of new oil and gas drilling, a deeply unpopular threat to Floridaâs natural environment and tourism-based economy.â The former vice president also said Trumpâs âmismanagementâ of the coronavirus crisis has âcost too many North Carolinians their lives and livelihoods, with communities of color bearing the brunt of the devastation.â During his speech in Jupiter, Fla., Trump announced and then proceeded to sign what he described as a âpresidential order extending the moratorium on offshore drilling on Floridaâs Gulf Coast and expanding it to Floridaâs Atlantic coast, as well as the coasts of Georgia and South Carolina.â The moratorium had been expected to expire in 2022.
